member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_NONE
member.summary: No hint for edited property.

member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_RANGE
member.summary: Hints that the string is a range, defined as \"min,max\" or \"min,max,step\". This is valid for integers and floats.

member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_EXP_RANGE
member.summary: Hints that the string is an exponential range, defined as \"min,max\" or \"min,max,step\". This is valid for integers and floats.

member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_ENUM
member.summary: Property hint for an enumerated value, like \"Hello,Something,Else\". This is valid for integer, float and string properties.

member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_FLAGS
member.summary: Property hint for a bitmask description, for bits 0,1,2,3 and 5 the hint would be like \"Bit0,Bit1,Bit2,Bit3,,Bit5\". Valid only for integers.

member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_FILE
member.summary: String property is a file (so pop up a file dialog when edited). Hint string can be a set of wildcards like \"*.doc\".

member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_DIR
member.summary: String property is a directory (so pop up a file dialog when edited).

member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_RESOURCE_TYPE
member.summary: String property is a resource, so open the resource popup menu when edited.

member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_IMAGE_COMPRESS_LOSSY
member.summary: Hints that the image is compressed using lossy compression.

member.name: F:Godot.GD.PROPERTY_HINT_IMAGE_COMPRESS_LOSSLESS
member.summary: Hints that the image is compressed using lossless compression.

member.name: T:Godot.AcceptDialog
member.summary: This dialog is useful for small notifications to the user about an event. It can only be accepted or closed, with the same result.

member.name: P:Godot.AcceptDialog.DialogText
member.summary: The text displayed by this dialog.

member.name: P:Godot.AcceptDialog.DialogHideOnOk
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the dialog is hidden when accepted. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: M:Godot.AcceptDialog.GetOk
member.summary: Return the OK Button.

member.name: M:Godot.AcceptDialog.GetLabel
member.summary: Return the label used for built-in text.

member.name: M:Godot.AcceptDialog.SetHideOnOk(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set whether the dialog is hidden when accepted (default true).

member.name: M:Godot.AcceptDialog.GetHideOnOk
member.summary: Return true if the dialog will be hidden when accepted (default true).

member.name: M:Godot.AcceptDialog.AddButton(System.String,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a button with label [i]text[/i] and a custom [i]action[/i] to the dialog and returns the created button. [i]action[/i] will be passed to the [custom_action] signal when pressed. If [code]true[/code], [i]right[/i] will place the button to the right of any sibling buttons. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: M:Godot.AcceptDialog.AddCancel(System.String)
member.summary: Adds a button with label [i]name[/i] and a cancel action to the dialog and returns the created button.

member.name: M:Godot.AcceptDialog.RegisterTextEnter(Godot.Node)
member.summary: Registers a [LineEdit] in the dialog. When the enter key is pressed, the dialog will be accepted.

member.name: M:Godot.AcceptDialog.SetText(System.String)
member.summary: Set the built-in label text.

member.name: M:Godot.AcceptDialog.GetText
member.summary: Return the built-in label text.

member.name: T:Godot.AnimatedSprite
member.summary: Animations are created using a [SpriteFrames] resource, which can be configured in the editor via the SpriteFrames panel.

member.name: P:Godot.AnimatedSprite.Frames
member.summary: The [SpriteFrames] resource containing the animation(s).

member.name: P:Godot.AnimatedSprite.Animation
member.summary: The current animation from the [code]frames[/code] resource. If this value changes, the [code]frame[/code] counter is reset.

member.name: P:Godot.AnimatedSprite.Frame
member.summary: The displayed animation frame's index.

member.name: P:Godot.AnimatedSprite.Playing
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the [member animation] is currently playing.

member.name: P:Godot.AnimatedSprite.Centered
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] texture will be centered. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AnimatedSprite.Offset
member.summary: The texture's drawing offset.

member.name: P:Godot.AnimatedSprite.FlipH
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] texture is flipped horizontally. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AnimatedSprite.FlipV
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] texture is flipped vertically. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.SetSpriteFrames(Godot.SpriteFrames)
member.summary: Set the [SpriteFrames] resource, which contains all frames.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.GetSpriteFrames
member.summary: Get the [SpriteFrames] resource, which contains all frames.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.SetAnimation(System.String)
member.summary: Set the current animation of the node and reinits the frame counter of the animation.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.GetAnimation
member.summary: Return the name of the current animation set to the node.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.Play(System.String)
member.summary: Play the animation set in parameter. If no parameter is provided, the current animation is played.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.Stop
member.summary: Stop the current animation (does not reset the frame counter).

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.IsPlaying
member.summary: Return true if an animation if currently being played.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.SetCentered(System.Boolean)
member.summary: When turned on, offset at (0,0) is the center of the sprite, when off, the top-left corner is.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.IsCentered
member.summary: Return true when centered. See [method set_centered].

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.SetOffset(Godot.Vector2)
member.summary: Set the offset of the sprite in the node origin. Position varies depending on whether it is centered or not.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.GetOffset
member.summary: Return the offset of the sprite in the node origin.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.SetFlipH(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If true, sprite is flipped horizontally.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.IsFlippedH
member.summary: Return true if sprite is flipped horizontally.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.SetFlipV(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If true, sprite is flipped vertically.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.IsFlippedV
member.summary: Return true if sprite is flipped vertically.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.SetFrame(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the visible sprite frame index (from the list of frames inside the [SpriteFrames] resource).

member.name: M:Godot.AnimatedSprite.GetFrame
member.summary: Return the visible frame index.

member.name: T:Godot.Animation
member.summary: An Animation resource contains data used to animate everything in the engine. Animations are divided into tracks, and each track must be linked to a node. The state of that node can be changed through time, by adding timed keys (events) to the track. Animations are just data containers, and must be added to odes such as an [AnimationPlayer] or [AnimationTreePlayer] to be played back.

member.name: F:Godot.Animation.TYPE_VALUE
member.summary: Value tracks set values in node properties, but only those which can be Interpolated.

member.name: F:Godot.Animation.TYPE_TRANSFORM
member.summary: Transform tracks are used to change node local transforms or skeleton pose bones. Transitions are Interpolated.

member.name: F:Godot.Animation.TYPE_METHOD
member.summary: Method tracks call functions with given arguments per key.

member.name: F:Godot.Animation.INTERPOLATION_NEAREST
member.summary: No interpolation (nearest value).

member.name: F:Godot.Animation.INTERPOLATION_LINEAR
member.summary: Linear interpolation.

member.name: F:Godot.Animation.INTERPOLATION_CUBIC
member.summary: Cubic interpolation.

member.name: F:Godot.Animation.UPDATE_CONTINUOUS
member.summary: Update between keyframes.

member.name: F:Godot.Animation.UPDATE_DISCRETE
member.summary: Update at the keyframes and hold the value.

member.name: F:Godot.Animation.UPDATE_TRIGGER
member.summary: Update at the keyframes.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.AddTrack(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Add a track to the Animation. The track type must be specified as any of the values in the TYPE_* enumeration.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.RemoveTrack(System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove a track by specifying the track index.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.GetTrackCount
member.summary: Return the amount of tracks in the animation.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackGetType(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the type of a track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackGetPath(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the path of a track. for more information on the path format, see [method track_set_path]

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackSetPath(System.Int32,Godot.NodePath)
member.summary: Set the path of a track. Paths must be valid scene-tree paths to a node, and must be specified starting from the parent node of the node that will reproduce the animation. Tracks that control properties or bones must append their name after the path, separated by ":". Example: "character/skeleton:ankle" or "character/mesh:transform/local"

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.FindTrack(Godot.NodePath)
member.summary: Return the index of the specified track. If the track is not found, return -1.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackMoveUp(System.Int32)
member.summary: Move a track up.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackMoveDown(System.Int32)
member.summary: Move a track down.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackSetImported(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set the given track as imported or not.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackIsImported(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return true if the given track is imported. Else, return false.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TransformTrackInsertKey(System.Int32,System.Single,Godot.Vector3,Godot.Quat,Godot.Vector3)
member.summary: Insert a transform key for a transform track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackInsertKey(System.Int32,System.Single,System.Object,System.Single)
member.summary: Insert a generic key in a given track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackRemoveKey(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Remove a key by index in a given track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackRemoveKeyAtPosition(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Remove a key by position (seconds) in a given track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackSetKeyValue(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Object)
member.summary: Set the value of an existing key.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackSetKeyTransition(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Set the transition curve (easing) for a specific key (see built-in math function "ease").

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackGetKeyTransition(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the transition curve (easing) for a specific key (see built-in math function "ease").

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackGetKeyCount(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the amount of keys in a given track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackGetKeyValue(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the value of a given key in a given track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackGetKeyTime(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the time at which the key is located.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackFindKey(System.Int32,System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Find the key index by time in a given track. Optionally, only find it if the exact time is given.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackSetInterpolationType(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the interpolation type of a given track, from the INTERPOLATION_* enum.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TrackGetInterpolationType(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the interpolation type of a given track, from the INTERPOLATION_* enum.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.TransformTrackInterpolate(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Return the interpolated value of a transform track at a given time (in seconds). An array consisting of 3 elements: position ([Vector3]), rotation ([Quat]) and scale ([Vector3]).

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.ValueTrackSetUpdateMode(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the update mode (UPDATE_*) of a value track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.ValueTrackGetUpdateMode(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the update mode of a value track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.ValueTrackGetKeyIndices(System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Return all the key indices of a value track, given a position and delta time.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.MethodTrackGetKeyIndices(System.Int32,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Return all the key indices of a method track, given a position and delta time.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.MethodTrackGetName(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the method name of a method track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.MethodTrackGetParams(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Return the arguments values to be called on a method track for a given key in a given track.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.SetLength(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the total length of the animation (in seconds). Note that length is not delimited by the last key, as this one may be before or after the end to ensure correct interpolation and looping.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.GetLength
member.summary: Return the total length of the animation (in seconds).

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.SetLoop(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set a flag indicating that the animation must loop. This is uses for correct interpolation of animation cycles, and for hinting the player that it must restart the animation.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.HasLoop
member.summary: Return whether the animation has the loop flag set.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.SetStep(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the animation step value.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.GetStep
member.summary: Get the animation step value.

member.name: M:Godot.Animation.Clear
member.summary: Clear the animation (clear all tracks and reset all).

member.name: T:Godot.AnimationPlayer
member.summary: An animation player is used for general purpose playback of [Animation] resources. It contains a dictionary of animations (referenced by name) and custom blend times between their transitions. Additionally, animations can be played and blended in different channels.

member.name: F:Godot.AnimationPlayer.ANIMATION_PROCESS_PHYSICS
member.summary: Process animation during the physics process. This is specially useful when animating physics bodies.

member.name: F:Godot.AnimationPlayer.ANIMATION_PROCESS_IDLE
member.summary: Process animation during the idle process.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.AddAnimation(System.String,Godot.Animation)
member.summary: Add an animation resource to the player, which will be later referenced by the "name" argument.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.RemoveAnimation(System.String)
member.summary: Remove an animation from the player (by supplying the same name used to add it).

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.RenameAnimation(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Rename an existing animation.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.HasAnimation(System.String)
member.summary: Request whether an [Animation] name exist within the player.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.GetAnimation(System.String)
member.summary: Get an [Animation] resource by requesting a name.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.GetAnimationList
member.summary: Get the list of names of the animations stored in the player.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.AnimationSetNext(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Set the name of an animation that will be played after.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.AnimationGetNext(System.String)
member.summary: Return the name of the next animation in the queue.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.SetBlendTime(System.String,System.String,System.Single)
member.summary: Specify a blend time (in seconds) between two animations, referenced by their names.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.GetBlendTime(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Get the blend time between two animations, referenced by their names.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.SetDefaultBlendTime(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the default blend time between animations.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.GetDefaultBlendTime
member.summary: Return the default blend time between animations.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.Play(System.String,System.Single,System.Single,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Play a given animation by the animation name. Custom speed and blend times can be set. If custom speed is negative (-1), 'from_end' being true can play the animation backwards.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.PlayBackwards(System.String,System.Single)
member.summary: Play a given animation by the animation name in reverse.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.Stop(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Stop the currently playing animation.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.StopAll
member.summary: Stop playback of animations (deprecated).

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.IsPlaying
member.summary: Return whether an animation is playing.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.SetCurrentAnimation(System.String)
member.summary: Set the current animation (even if no playback occurs). Using set_current_animation() and set_active() are similar to calling play().

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.GetCurrentAnimation
member.summary: Return the name of the animation being played.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.Queue(System.String)
member.summary: Queue an animation for playback once the current one is done.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.ClearQueue
member.summary: If animations are queued to play, clear them.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.SetActive(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set the player as active (playing). If false, it will do nothing.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.IsActive
member.summary: Return true if the player is active.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.SetSpeedScale(System.Single)
member.summary: Set a speed scaling ratio in a given animation channel (or channel 0 if none is provided). Default ratio is [i]1[/i] (no scaling).

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.GetSpeedScale
member.summary: Get the speed scaling ratio in a given animation channel (or channel 0 if none is provided). Default ratio is [i]1[/i] (no scaling).

member.summary: Set the name of the animation that will be automatically played when the scene is loaded.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.GetAutoplay
member.summary: Return the name of the animation that will be automatically played when the scene is loaded.

member.summary: AnimationPlayer resolves animation track paths from this node (which is relative to itself), by default root is "..", but it can be changed.

member.summary: Return path to root node (see [method set_root]).

member.summary: Seek the animation to a given position in time (in seconds). If 'update' is true, the animation will be updated too, otherwise it will be updated at process time.

member.summary: Return the playback position (in seconds) in an animation channel (or channel 0 if none is provided).

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.ClearCaches
member.summary: The animation player creates caches for faster access to the nodes it will animate. However, if a specific node is removed, it may not notice it, so clear_caches will force the player to search for the nodes again.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.SetAnimationProcessMode(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the mode in which the animation player processes. By default, it processes on idle time (framerate dependent), but using fixed time works well for animating static collision bodies in 2D and 3D. See enum ANIMATION_PROCESS_*.

member.summary: Return the mode in which the animation player processes. See [method set_animation_process_mode].

member.summary: Get the position (in seconds) of the currently being played animation.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.GetCurrentAnimationLength
member.summary: Get the length (in seconds) of the currently being played animation.

member.name: M:Godot.AnimationPlayer.Advance(System.Single)
member.summary: Used to skip ahead or skip back in an animation. Delta is the time in seconds to skip.

member.name: T:Godot.Area
member.summary: 3D area that detects [CollisionObject] nodes overlapping, entering, or exiting. Can also alter or override local physics parameters (gravity, damping).

member.name: F:Godot.Area.SPACE_OVERRIDE_DISABLED
member.summary: This area does not affect gravity/damping.

member.name: F:Godot.Area.SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE
member.summary: This area adds its gravity/damping values to whatever has been calculated so far (in [code]priority[/code] order).

member.name: F:Godot.Area.SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE_REPLACE
member.summary: This area adds its gravity/damping values to whatever has been calculated so far (in [code]priority[/code] order), ignoring any lower priority areas.

member.name: F:Godot.Area.SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE
member.summary: This area replaces any gravity/damping, even the defaults, ignoring any lower priority areas.

member.name: F:Godot.Area.SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE_COMBINE
member.summary: This area replaces any gravity/damping calculated so far (in [code]priority[/code] order), but keeps calculating the rest of the areas.

member.name: P:Godot.Area.SpaceOverride
member.summary: Override mode for gravity and damping calculations within this area. See the SPACE_OVERRIDE_* constants for values.

member.name: P:Godot.Area.GravityPoint
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] gravity is calculated from a point (set via [code]gravity_vec[/code]). Also see [code]space_override[/code]. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area.GravityDistanceScale
member.summary: The falloff factor for point gravity. The greater the value, the faster gravity decreases with distance.

member.name: P:Godot.Area.GravityVec
member.summary: The area's gravity vector (not normalized). If gravity is a point (see [method is_gravity_a_point]), this will be the point of attraction.

member.name: P:Godot.Area.Gravity
member.summary: The area's gravity intensity (ranges from -1024 to 1024). This value multiplies the gravity vector. This is useful to alter the force of gravity without altering its direction.

member.name: P:Godot.Area.LinearDamp
member.summary: The rate at which objects stop moving in this area. Represents the linear velocity lost per second. Values range from [code]0[/code] (no damping) to [code]1[/code] (full damping).

member.name: P:Godot.Area.AngularDamp
member.summary: The rate at which objects stop spinning in this area. Represents the angular velocity lost per second. Values range from [code]0[/code] (no damping) to [code]1[/code] (full damping).

member.name: P:Godot.Area.Priority
member.summary: The area's priority. Higher priority areas are processed first. Default value: 0.

member.name: P:Godot.Area.Monitoring
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the area detects bodies or areas entering and exiting it. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area.Monitorable
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] other monitoring areas can detect this area. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area.CollisionLayer
member.summary: The area's physics layer(s). Collidable objects can exist in any of 32 different layers. A contact is detected if object A is in any of the layers that object B scans, or object B is in any layers that object A scans. See also [code]collision_mask[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area.CollisionMask
member.summary: The physics layers this area scans to determine collision detection.

member.name: P:Godot.Area.AudioBusOverride
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the area's audio bus overrides the default audio bus. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area.AudioBusName
member.summary: The name of the area's audio bus.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetSpaceOverrideMode(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the space override mode. This mode controls how an area affects gravity and damp. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_DISABLED: This area does not affect gravity/damp. These are generally areas that exist only to detect collisions, and objects entering or exiting them. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE: This area adds its gravity/damp values to whatever has been calculated so far. This way, many overlapping areas can combine their physics to make interesting effects. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE_REPLACE: This area adds its gravity/damp values to whatever has been calculated so far. Then stops taking into account the rest of the areas, even the default one. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE: This area replaces any gravity/damp, even the default one, and stops taking into account the rest of the areas. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE_COMBINE: This area replaces any gravity/damp calculated so far, but keeps calculating the rest of the areas, down to the default one.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetSpaceOverrideMode
member.summary: Return the space override mode.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetGravityIsPoint(System.Boolean)
member.summary: When overriding space parameters, this method sets whether this area has a center of gravity. To set/get the location of the center of gravity, use [method set_gravity_vector]/[method get_gravity_vector].

member.name: M:Godot.Area.IsGravityAPoint
member.summary: Return whether gravity is a point. A point gravity will attract objects towards it, as opposed to a gravity vector, which moves them in a given direction.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetGravityDistanceScale(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the falloff factor for point gravity. The greater this value is, the faster the strength of gravity decreases with the square of distance.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetGravityDistanceScale
member.summary: Return the falloff factor for point gravity.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetGravityVector(Godot.Vector3)
member.summary: Set the gravity vector. This vector does not have to be normalized. If gravity is a point (see [method is_gravity_a_point]), this will be the attraction center.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetGravityVector
member.summary: Return the gravity vector. If gravity is a point (see [method is_gravity_a_point]), this will be the attraction center.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetGravity(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the gravity intensity. This is useful to alter the force of gravity without altering its direction. This value multiplies the gravity vector, whether it is the given vector ([method set_gravity_vector]), or a calculated one (when using a center of gravity).

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetGravity
member.summary: Return the gravity intensity.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetAngularDamp(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the rate at which objects stop spinning in this area, if there are not any other forces making it spin. The value is a fraction of its current speed, lost per second. Thus, a value of 1.0 should mean stopping immediately, and 0.0 means the object never stops. In practice, as the fraction of speed lost gets smaller with each frame, a value of 1.0 does not mean the object will stop in exactly one second. Only when the physics calculations are done at 1 frame per second, it does stop in a second.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetAngularDamp
member.summary: Return the angular damp rate.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetLinearDamp(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the rate at which objects stop moving in this area, if there are not any other forces moving it. The value is a fraction of its current speed, lost per second. Thus, a value of 1.0 should mean stopping immediately, and 0.0 means the object never stops. In practice, as the fraction of speed lost gets smaller with each frame, a value of 1.0 does not mean the object will stop in exactly one second. Only when the physics calculations are done at 1 frame per second, it does stop in a second.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetLinearDamp
member.summary: Return the linear damp rate.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetPriority(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the order in which the area is processed. Greater values mean the area gets processed first. This is useful for areas which have a space override different from AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_DISABLED or AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE, as they replace values, and are thus order-dependent. Areas with the same priority value get evaluated in an unpredictable order, and should be differentiated if evaluation order is to be important.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetPriority
member.summary: Return the processing order of this area.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetCollisionMask(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the physics layers this area can scan for collisions.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetCollisionMask
member.summary: Return the physics layers this area can scan for collisions.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetCollisionLayer(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the physics layers this area is in. Collidable objects can exist in any of 32 different layers. These layers are not visual, but more of a tagging system instead. A collidable can use these layers/tags to select with which objects it can collide, using [method set_collision_mask]. A contact is detected if object A is in any of the layers that object B scans, or object B is in any layer scanned by object A.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetCollisionLayer
member.summary: Return the physics layer this area is in.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetCollisionMaskBit(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set/clear individual bits on the collision mask. This makes selecting the areas scanned easier.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetCollisionMaskBit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return an individual bit on the collision mask.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetCollisionLayerBit(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set/clear individual bits on the layer mask. This makes getting an area in/out of only one layer easier.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetCollisionLayerBit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return an individual bit on the layer mask.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetMonitorable(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set whether this area can be detected by other, monitoring, areas. Only areas need to be marked as monitorable. Bodies are always so.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.IsMonitorable
member.summary: Return whether this area can be detected by other, monitoring, areas.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.SetMonitoring(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set whether this area can detect bodies/areas entering/exiting it.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.IsMonitoring
member.summary: Return whether this area detects bodies/areas entering/exiting it.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetOverlappingBodies
member.summary: Returns a list of intersecting [PhysicsBody]s.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.GetOverlappingAreas
member.summary: Returns a list of intersecting [code]Area[/code]s.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.OverlapsBody(Godot.Node)
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the given body overlaps the Area.

member.name: M:Godot.Area.OverlapsArea(Godot.Node)
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the given area overlaps the Area.

member.name: T:Godot.Area2D
member.summary: 2D area that detects [CollisionObject2D] nodes overlapping, entering, or exiting. Can also alter or override local physics parameters (gravity, damping).

member.summary: This area does not affect gravity/damping.

member.name: F:Godot.Area2D.SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE
member.summary: This area adds its gravity/damping values to whatever has been calculated so far (in [code]priority[/code] order).

member.name: F:Godot.Area2D.SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE_REPLACE
member.summary: This area adds its gravity/damping values to whatever has been calculated so far (in [code]priority[/code] order), ignoring any lower priority areas.

member.name: F:Godot.Area2D.SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE
member.summary: This area replaces any gravity/damping, even the defaults, ignoring any lower priority areas.

member.name: F:Godot.Area2D.SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE_COMBINE
member.summary: This area replaces any gravity/damping calculated so far (in [code]priority[/code] order), but keeps calculating the rest of the areas.

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.SpaceOverride
member.summary: Override mode for gravity and damping calculations within this area. See the SPACE_OVERRIDE_* constants for values.

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.GravityPoint
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] gravity is calculated from a point (set via [code]gravity_vec[/code]). Also see [code]space_override[/code]. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.GravityDistanceScale
member.summary: The falloff factor for point gravity. The greater the value, the faster gravity decreases with distance.

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.GravityVec
member.summary: The area's gravity vector (not normalized). If gravity is a point (see [method is_gravity_a_point]), this will be the point of attraction.

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.Gravity
member.summary: The area's gravity intensity (ranges from -1024 to 1024). This value multiplies the gravity vector. This is useful to alter the force of gravity without altering its direction.

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.LinearDamp
member.summary: The rate at which objects stop moving in this area. Represents the linear velocity lost per second. Values range from [code]0[/code] (no damping) to [code]1[/code] (full damping).

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.AngularDamp
member.summary: The rate at which objects stop spinning in this area. Represents the angular velocity lost per second. Values range from [code]0[/code] (no damping) to [code]1[/code] (full damping).

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.Priority
member.summary: The area's priority. Higher priority areas are processed first. Default value: 0.

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.Monitoring
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the area detects bodies or areas entering and exiting it. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.Monitorable
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] other monitoring areas can detect this area. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.CollisionLayer
member.summary: The area's physics layer(s). Collidable objects can exist in any of 32 different layers. A contact is detected if object A is in any of the layers that object B scans, or object B is in any layers that object A scans. See also [code]collision_mask[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.CollisionMask
member.summary: The physics layers this area scans to determine collision detection.

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.AudioBusOverride
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the area's audio bus overrides the default audio bus. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.Area2D.AudioBusName
member.summary: The name of the area's audio bus.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetSpaceOverrideMode(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the space override mode. This mode controls how an area affects gravity and damp. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_DISABLED: This area does not affect gravity/damp. These are generally areas that exist only to detect collisions, and objects entering or exiting them. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE: This area adds its gravity/damp values to whatever has been calculated so far. This way, many overlapping areas can combine their physics to make interesting effects. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE_REPLACE: This area adds its gravity/damp values to whatever has been calculated so far. Then stops taking into account the rest of the areas, even the default one. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE: This area replaces any gravity/damp, even the default one, and stops taking into account the rest of the areas. AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_REPLACE_COMBINE: This area replaces any gravity/damp calculated so far, but keeps calculating the rest of the areas, down to the default one.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetSpaceOverrideMode
member.summary: Return the space override mode.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetGravityIsPoint(System.Boolean)
member.summary: When overriding space parameters, this method sets whether this area has a center of gravity. To set/get the location of the center of gravity, use [method set_gravity_vector]/[method get_gravity_vector].

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.IsGravityAPoint
member.summary: Return whether gravity is a point. A point gravity will attract objects towards it, as opposed to a gravity vector, which moves them in a given direction.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetGravityDistanceScale(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the falloff factor for point gravity. The greater this value is, the faster the strength of gravity decreases with the square of distance.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetGravityDistanceScale
member.summary: Return the falloff factor for point gravity.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetGravityVector(Godot.Vector2)
member.summary: Set the gravity vector. This vector does not have to be normalized. If gravity is a point (see [method is_gravity_a_point]), this will be the attraction center.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetGravityVector
member.summary: Return the gravity vector. If gravity is a point (see [method is_gravity_a_point]), this will be the attraction center.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetGravity(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the gravity intensity. This is useful to alter the force of gravity without altering its direction. This value multiplies the gravity vector, whether it is the given vector ([method set_gravity_vector]), or a calculated one (when using a center of gravity).

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetGravity
member.summary: Return the gravity intensity.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetLinearDamp(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the rate at which objects stop moving in this area, if there are not any other forces moving it. The value is a fraction of its current speed, lost per second. Thus, a value of 1.0 should mean stopping immediately, and 0.0 means the object never stops. In practice, as the fraction of speed lost gets smaller with each frame, a value of 1.0 does not mean the object will stop in exactly one second. Only when the physics calculations are done at 1 frame per second, it does stop in a second.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetLinearDamp
member.summary: Return the linear damp rate.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetAngularDamp(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the rate at which objects stop spinning in this area, if there are not any other forces making it spin. The value is a fraction of its current speed, lost per second. Thus, a value of 1.0 should mean stopping immediately, and 0.0 means the object never stops. In practice, as the fraction of speed lost gets smaller with each frame, a value of 1.0 does not mean the object will stop in exactly one second. Only when the physics calculations are done at 1 frame per second, it does stop in a second.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetAngularDamp
member.summary: Return the angular damp rate.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetPriority(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the order in which the area is processed. Greater values mean the area gets processed first. This is useful for areas which have a space override different from AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_DISABLED or AREA_SPACE_OVERRIDE_COMBINE, as they replace values, and are thus order-dependent. Areas with the same priority value get evaluated in an unpredictable order, and should be differentiated if evaluation order is to be important.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetPriority
member.summary: Return the processing order of this area.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetCollisionMask(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the physics layers this area can scan for collisions.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetCollisionMask
member.summary: Return the physics layers this area will scan to determine collisions.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetCollisionLayer(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the physics layers this area is in. Collidable objects can exist in any of 32 different layers. These layers are not visual, but more of a tagging system instead. A collidable can use these layers/tags to select with which objects it can collide, using [method set_collision_mask]. A contact is detected if object A is in any of the layers that object B scans, or object B is in any layer scanned by object A.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetCollisionLayer
member.summary: Return the physics layer this area is in.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetCollisionMaskBit(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set/clear individual bits on the collision mask. This makes selecting the areas scanned easier.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetCollisionMaskBit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return an individual bit on the collision mask. Describes whether this area will collide with others on the given layer.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetCollisionLayerBit(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set/clear individual bits on the layer mask. This makes getting an area in/out of only one layer easier.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.GetCollisionLayerBit(System.Int32)
member.summary: Return an individual bit on the layer mask. Describes whether other areas will collide with this one on the given layer.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetMonitoring(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set whether this area can detect bodies/areas entering/exiting it.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.IsMonitoring
member.summary: Return whether this area detects bodies/areas entering/exiting it.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.SetMonitorable(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set whether this area can be detected by other, monitoring, areas. Only areas need to be marked as monitorable. Bodies are always so.

member.name: M:Godot.Area2D.IsMonitorable
member.summary: Return whether this area can be detected by other, monitoring, areas.

member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the given body overlaps the Area2D.

member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the given area overlaps the Area2D.

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRAnchor
member.summary: The ARVR Anchor point is a spatial node that maps a real world location identified by the AR platform to a position within the game world. For example, as long as plane detection in ARKit is on, ARKit will identify and update the position of planes (tables, floors, etc) and create anchors for them. This node is mapped to one of the anchors through its unique id. When you receive a signal that a new anchor is available you should add this node to your scene for that anchor. You can predefine nodes and set the id and the nodes will simply remain on 0,0,0 until a plane is recognised. Keep in mind that as long as plane detection is enable the size, placing and orientation of an anchor will be updates as the detection logic learns more about the real world out there especially if only part of the surface is in view.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRAnchor.AnchorId
member.summary: The anchor's id. You can set this before the anchor itself exists. The first anchor gets an id of [code]1[/code], the second an id of [code]2[/code], etc. When anchors get removed, the engine can then assign the corresponding id to new anchors. The most common situation where anchors 'disappear' is when the AR server identifies that two anchors represent different parts of the same plane and merges them.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.SetAnchorId(System.Int32)
member.summary: Binds this anchor node to an anchor with this id. You can set this before the anchor itself exists. The first anchor that is identified gets id 1, the second id 2, etc. When anchors get removed that slot remains free and can be assigned to the next anchor that is identified. The most common situation where anchors 'disappear' is when the AR server identifies that two anchors represent different parts of the same plane and merge them.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.GetAnchorId
member.summary: Returns the anchor id for this anchor.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.GetAnchorName
member.summary: Returns the name given to this anchor.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.GetIsActive
member.summary: Returns true if the anchor is being tracked and false if no anchor with this id is currently known.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.GetSize
member.summary: Returns the estimated size of the plane that was detected. Say when the anchor relates to a table in the real world, this is the estimated size of the surface of that table.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRAnchor.GetPlane
member.summary: Returns a plane aligned with our anchor, handy for intersection testing

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRCamera
member.summary: This is a helper spatial node for our camera, note that if stereoscopic rendering is applicable (VR-HMD) most of the camera properties are ignored as the HMD information overrides them. The only properties that can be trusted are the near and far planes. The position and orientation of this node is automatically updated by the ARVR Server to represent the location of the HMD if such tracking is available and can thus be used by game logic. Note that in contrast to the ARVR Controller the render thread has access to the most up to date tracking data of the HMD and the location of the ARVRCamera can lag a few milliseconds behind what is used for rendering as a result.

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRController
member.summary: This is a helper spatial node that is linked to the tracking of controllers. It also offers several handy pass throughs to the state of buttons and such on the controllers. Controllers are linked by their id. You can create controller nodes before the controllers are available. Say your game always uses two controllers (one for each hand) you can predefine the controllers with id 1 and 2 and they will become active as soon as the controllers are identified. If you expect additional controllers to be used you should react to the signals and add ARVRController nodes to your scene. The position of the controller node is automatically updated by the ARVR Server. This makes this node ideal to add child nodes to visualise the controller.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRController.ControllerId
member.summary: The controller's id. The first controller that the [ARVRServer] detects will have id 1, the second id 2, the third id 3, etc. When a controller is turned off, it's slot is freed. This ensures controllers will keep the same id even when controllers with lower ids are turned off.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.SetControllerId(System.Int32)
member.summary: Changes the id that identifies the controller bound to this node. The first controller that the ARVR Server detects will have id 1, the second id 2, the third id 3, etc. When a controller is turned off that slot is freed ensuring that controllers will keep the same id while it is turned on even when controllers with lower ids are turned off.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetControllerId
member.summary: Returns the controller id currently assigned to this node.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetControllerName
member.summary: If active, returns the name of the associated controller if provided by the AR/VR SDK used.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetJoystickId
member.summary: Returns the ID of the joystick object bound to this. Every controller tracked by the ARVR Server that has buttons and axis will also be registered as a joystick within Godot. This means that all the normal joystick tracking and input mapping will work for buttons and axis found on the AR/VR controllers. This ID is purely offered as information so you can link up the controller with its joystick entry.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.IsButtonPressed(System.Int32)
member.summary: Is the given button currently pressed?

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetJoystickAxis(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the value of the given axis for things like triggers, touchpads, etc. that are embedded into the controller.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetIsActive
member.summary: Returns true if the controller bound to this node is currently active and being tracked.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRController.GetHand
member.summary: Returns the hand holding this controller, if known. See TRACKER_* constants in [ARVRPositionalTracker].

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRInterface
member.summary: This class needs to be implemented to make an AR or VR platform available to Godot and these should be implemented as C++ modules or GDNative modules (note that for GDNative the subclass ARVRScriptInterface should be used). Part of the interface is exposed to GDScript so you can detect, enable and configure an AR or VR platform. Interfaces should be written in such a way that simply enabling them will give us a working setup. You can query the available interfaces through ARVRServer.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_NONE
member.summary: No ARVR capabilities.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_MONO
member.summary: This interface can work with normal rendering output (non-HMD based AR).

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_STEREO
member.summary: This interface supports stereoscopic rendering.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_AR
member.summary: This interface support AR (video background and real world tracking).

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_EXTERNAL
member.summary: This interface outputs to an external device, if the main viewport is used the on screen output is an unmodified buffer of either the left or right eye (stretched if the viewport size is not changed to the same aspect ratio of get_recommended_render_targetsize. Using a seperate viewport node frees up the main viewport for other purposes.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.EYE_MONO
member.summary: Mono output, this is mostly used internally when retrieving positioning information for our camera node or when stereo scopic rendering is not supported.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.EYE_LEFT
member.summary: Left eye output, this is mostly used internally when rendering the image for the left eye and obtaining positioning and projection information.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.EYE_RIGHT
member.summary: Right eye output, this is mostly used internally when rendering the image for the right eye and obtaining positioning and projection information.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_NORMAL_TRACKING
member.summary: Tracking is behaving as expected.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_EXCESSIVE_MOTION
member.summary: Tracking is hindered by excessive motion, player is moving faster then tracking can keep up.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_INSUFFICIENT_FEATURES
member.summary: Tracking is hindered by insufficient features, it's too dark (for camera based tracking), player is blocked, etc.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_UNKNOWN_TRACKING
member.summary: We don't know the status of the tracking or this interface does not provide feedback.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRInterface.ARVR_NOT_TRACKING
member.summary: Tracking is not functional (camera not plugged in or obscured, lighthouses turned off, etc.)

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRInterface.InterfaceIsPrimary
member.summary: Is this our primary interface?

member.summary: Has this interface been initialized?

member.name: P:Godot.ARVRInterface.ArIsAnchorDetectionEnabled
member.summary: On an AR interface, is our anchor detection enabled?

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.GetName
member.summary: Returns the name of this interface (OpenVR, OpenHMD, ARKit, etc).

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.GetCapabilities
member.summary: Returns a combination of flags providing information about the capabilities of this interface.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.IsPrimary
member.summary: Returns true if this interface is currently the primary interface (the interface responsible for showing the output).

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.SetIsPrimary(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set this interface to the primary interface (unset the old one).

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.IsInitialized
member.summary: Returns true if this interface is active.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.SetIsInitialized(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initialize/uninitialize this interface (same effect as calling initialize/uninitialize).

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.Initialize
member.summary: Call this to initialize this interface. The first interface that is initialized is identified as the primary interface and it will be used for rendering output. After initializing the interface you want to use you then need to enable the AR/VR mode of a viewport and rendering should commence. Note that you must enable the AR/VR mode on the main viewport for any device that uses the main output of Godot such as for mobile VR. If you do this for a platform that handles its own output (such as OpenVR) Godot will show just one eye without distortion on screen. Alternatively you can add a separate viewport node to your scene and enable AR/VR on that viewport and it will be used to output to the HMD leaving you free to do anything you like in the main window such as using a separate camera as a spectator camera or render out something completely different. While currently not used you can activate additional interfaces, you may wish to do this if you want to track controllers from other platforms. However at this point in time only one interface can render to an HMD.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.Uninitialize
member.summary: Turns the interface off.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.GetTrackingStatus
member.summary: If supported, returns the status of our tracking. This will allow you to provide feedback to the user whether there are issues with positional tracking.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.GetRecommendedRenderTargetsize
member.summary: Returns the resolution at which we should render our intermediate results before things like lens distortion are applied by the VR platform.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.IsStereo
member.summary: Returns true if the current output of this interface is in stereo.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.GetAnchorDetectionIsEnabled
member.summary: Returns true if achor detection is enabled (AR only).

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRInterface.SetAnchorDetectionIsEnabled(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables anchor detection, this is used on AR interfaces and enables the extra logic that will detect planes, features, objects, etc. and adds/modifies anchor points.

member.name: T:Godot.ARVROrigin
member.summary: This is a special node within the AR/VR system that maps the physical location of the center of our tracking space to the virtual location within our game world. There should be only one of these nodes in your scene and you must have one. All the ARVRCamera, ARVRController and ARVRAnchor nodes should be direct children of this node for spatial tracking to work correctly. It is the position of this node that you update when you're character needs to move through your game world while we're not moving in the real world. Movement in the real world is always in relation to this origin point. So say that your character is driving a car, the ARVROrigin node should be a child node of this car. If you implement a teleport system to move your character, you change the position of this node. Etc.

member.name: P:Godot.ARVROrigin.WorldScale
member.summary: Allows you to adjust the scale to your game's units. Most AR/VR platforms assume a scale of 1 game world unit = 1 meter in the real world. Note that this method is a passthrough to the [ARVRServer] itself.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVROrigin.SetWorldScale(System.Single)
member.summary: Changes the world scaling factor. Most AR/VR platforms will assume a unit size of 1 unit in your game world = 1 meter in the real world. This scale allows you to adjust this to the unit system you use in your game. Note that this method is a passthrough to the ARVRServer itself.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVROrigin.GetWorldScale
member.summary: Get the world scale applied to our positioning.

member.name: T:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker
member.summary: An instance of this object represents a device that is tracked such as a controller or anchor point. HMDs aren't represented here as they are fully handled internally. As controllers are turned on and the AR/VR interface detects them instances of this object are automatically added to this list of active tracking objects accessible through the ARVRServer The ARVRController and ARVRAnchor both consume objects of this type and should be the objects you use in game. The positional trackers are just the under the hood objects that make this all work and are mostly exposed so GDNative based interfaces can interact with them.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.TRACKER_HAND_UNKNOWN
member.summary: The hand this tracker is held in is unknown or not applicable.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.TRACKER_LEFT_HAND
member.summary: This tracker is the left hand controller.

member.name: F:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.TRACKER_RIGHT_HAND
member.summary: This tracker is the right hand controller.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.GetType
member.summary: Type of tracker.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.GetName
member.summary: If available this returns the name of the controller or anchor point.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.GetJoyId
member.summary: If this is a controller that is being tracked the controller will also be represented by a joystick entry with this id.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRPositionalTracker.GetTracksOrientation
member.summary: Returns true if the orientation of this device is being tracked.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRServer.GetReferenceFrame

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRServer.CenterOnHmd(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This is a really important function to understand correctly. AR and VR platforms all handle positioning slightly differently. For platforms that do not offer spatial tracking our origin point (0,0,0) is the location of our HMD but you have little control over the direction the player is facing in the real world. For platforms that do offer spatial tracking our origin point depends very much on the system. For OpenVR our origin point is usually the center of the tracking space, on the ground. For other platforms its often the location of the tracking camera. This method allows you to center our tracker on the location of the HMD, it will take the current location of the HMD and use that to adjust all our tracking data in essence realigning the real world to your players current position in your game world. For this method to produce usable results tracking information should be available and this often takes a few frames after starting your game. You should call this method after a few seconds have passed, when the user requests a realignment of the display holding a designated button on a controller for a short period of time, and when implementing a teleport mechanism.

member.name: M:Godot.ARVRServer.GetInterfaceCount

If you're game supports multiple AR/VR platforms you can look throught the available interface and either present the user with a selection or simply try an initialize each interface and use the first one that returns true.

member.name: T:Godot.AStar
member.summary: A* (A star) is a computer algorithm that is widely used in pathfinding and graph traversal, the process of plotting an efficiently directed path between multiple points. It enjoys widespread use due to its performance and accuracy. Godot's A* implementation make use of vectors as points. You must add points manually with [method AStar.add_point] and create segments manually with [method AStar.connect_points]. So you can test if there is a path between two points with the [method AStar.are_points_connected] function, get the list of existing ids in the found path with [method AStar.get_id_path], or the points list with [method AStar.get_point_path].

member.name: M:Godot.AStar._ComputeCost(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Called when computing the cost between two connected points.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar._EstimateCost(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Called when estimating the cost between a point and the path's ending point.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetAvailablePointId
member.summary: Returns the next available point id with no point associated to it.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.AddPoint(System.Int32,Godot.Vector3,System.Single)
member.summary:
Adds a new point at the given position with the given identifier. The algorithm prefers points with lower [code]weight_scale[/code] to form a path. The [code]id[/code] must be 0 or larger, and the [code]weight_scale[/code] must be 1 or larger. [codeblock] var as = AStar.new()
as.add_point(1, Vector3(1,0,0), 4) # Adds the point (1,0,0) with weight_scale=4 and id=1 [/codeblock] If there already exists a point for the given id, its position and weight scale are updated to the given values.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetPointPosition(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the position of the point associated with the given id.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.SetPointPosition(System.Int32,Godot.Vector3)
member.summary: Sets the position for the point with the given id.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetPointWeightScale(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the weight scale of the point associated with the given id.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.SetPointWeightScale(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the [code]weight_scale[/code] for the point with the given id.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.RemovePoint(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the point associated with the given id from the points pool.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.HasPoint(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns whether a point associated with the given id exists.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.ConnectPoints(System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Creates a segment between the given points. [codeblock] var as = AStar.new()
as.add_point(1, Vector3(1,1,0)) as.add_point(2, Vector3(0,5,0))
as.connect_points(1, 2, false) # If bidirectional=false it's only possible to go from point 1 to point 2 # and not from point 2 to point 1. [/codeblock]

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.DisconnectPoints(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Deletes the segment between the given points.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.ArePointsConnected(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns whether there is a connection/segment between the given points.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.Clear
member.summary: Clears all the points and segments.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetClosestPoint(Godot.Vector3)
member.summary: Returns the id of the closest point to [code]to_position[/code]. Returns -1 if there are no points in the points pool.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetClosestPositionInSegment(Godot.Vector3)
member.summary:
Returns the closest position to [code]to_position[/code] that resides inside a segment between two connected points. [codeblock] var as = AStar.new()
as.add_point(1, Vector3(0,0,0)) as.add_point(2, Vector3(0,5,0))
as.connect_points(1, 2)
var res = as.get_closest_position_in_segment(Vector3(3,3,0)) # returns (0, 3, 0) [/codeblock] The result is in the segment that goes from [code]y=0[/code] to [code]y=5[/code]. It's the closest position in the segment to the given point.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetPointPath(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns an array with the points that are in the path found by AStar between the given points. The array is ordered from the starting point to the ending point of the path.

member.name: M:Godot.AStar.GetIdPath(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Returns an array with the ids of the points that form the path found by AStar between the given points. The array is ordered from the starting point to the ending point of the path. [codeblock] var as = AStar.new()
as.add_point(1, Vector3(0,0,0)) as.add_point(2, Vector3(0,1,0), 1) # default weight is 1 as.add_point(3, Vector3(1,1,0)) as.add_point(4, Vector3(2,0,0))
as.connect_points(1, 2, false) as.connect_points(2, 3, false) as.connect_points(4, 3, false) as.connect_points(1, 4, false) as.connect_points(5, 4, false)
var res = as.get_id_path(1, 3) # returns [1, 2, 3] [/codeblock] If you change the 2nd point's weight to 3, then the result will be [code][1, 4, 3][/code] instead, because now even though the distance is longer, it's "easier" to get through point 4 than through point 2.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor
member.summary: Dynamic range compressor reduces the level of the sound when the amplitude goes over a certain threshold in Decibels. One of the main uses of a compressor is to increase the dynamic range by clipping as little as possible (when sound goes over 0dB). Compressor has many uses in the mix: - In the Master bus to compress the whole output (Although a [AudioEffectLimiter] is probably better) - In voice channels to ensure they sound as balanced as possible. - Sidechained. Sidechained, which can reduce the sound level sidechained with another audio bus for threshold detection.. This technique is very common in video game mixing to download the level of Music/SFX while voices are being heard. - Accentuates transients by using a wider attack, making effects sound more punchy.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Threshold
member.summary: The level above which compression is applied to the audio. Value can range from -60 to 0. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Ratio
member.summary: Amount of compression applied to the audio once it passes the threshold level. The higher the ratio the more the loud parts of the audio will be compressed. Value can range from 1 to 48. Default value: [code]4[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Gain
member.summary: Gain applied to the output signal.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.AttackUs
member.summary: Compressor's reaction time when the signal exceeds the threshold. Value can range from 20 to 2000. Default value: [code]20ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.ReleaseMs
member.summary: Compressor's delay time to stop reducing the signal after the signal level falls below the threshold. Value can range from 20 to 2000. Default value: [code]250ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Mix
member.summary: Balance between original signal and effect signal. Value can range from 0 (totally dry) to 1 (totally wet). Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectCompressor.Sidechain
member.summary: Reduce the sound level using another audio bus for threshold detection.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectDelay
member.summary: Plays input signal back after a period of time. The delayed signal may be played back multiple times to create the sound of a repeating, decaying echo. Delay effects range from a subtle echo effect to a pronounced blending of previous sounds with new sounds.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Dry
member.summary: Output percent of original sound. At 0, only delayed sounds are output. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap1__active
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], [code]tap1[/code] will be enabled. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap1__delayMs
member.summary: [b]Tap1[/b] delay time in milliseconds. Default value: [code]250ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap1__levelDb
member.summary: Sound level for [code]tap1[/code]. Default value: [code]-6 dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap1__pan
member.summary: Pan position for [code]tap1[/code]. Value can range from -1 (fully left) to 1 (fully right). Default value: [code]0.2[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap2__active
member.summary: If [code]true[/code], [code]tap2[/code] will be enabled. Default value: [code]true[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap2__delayMs
member.summary: [b]Tap2[/b] delay time in milliseconds. Default value: [code]500ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap2__levelDb
member.summary: Sound level for [code]tap2[/code]. Default value: [code]-12 dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Tap2__pan
member.summary: Pan position for [code]tap2[/code]. Value can range from -1 (fully left) to 1 (fully right). Default value: [code]-0.4[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Feedback__active
member.summary: If [code]true[/code] feedback is enabled. Default value: [code]false[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Feedback__delayMs
member.summary: Feedback delay time in milliseconds. Default value: [code]340[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Feedback__levelDb
member.summary: Sound level for [code]tap1[/code]. Default value: [code]-6 dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDelay.Feedback__lowpass
member.summary: Low-pass filter for feedback. Frequencies below the Low Cut value are filtered out of the source signal. Default value: [code]16000[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion
member.summary: Modify the sound and make it dirty. Different types are available : clip, tan, lofi (bit crushing), overdrive, or waveshape. By distorting the waveform the frequency content change, which will often make the sound "crunchy" or "abrasive". For games, it can simulate sound coming from some saturated device or speaker very efficiently.

member.name: F:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.MODE_CLIP
member.summary: Digital distortion effect which cuts off peaks at the top and bottom of the waveform.

member.name: F:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.MODE_LOFI
member.summary: Low-resolution digital distortion effect. You can use it to emulate the sound of early digital audio devices.

member.name: F:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.MODE_OVERDRIVE
member.summary: Emulates the warm distortion produced by a field effect transistor, which is commonly used in solid-state musical instrument amplifiers.

member.name: F:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.MODE_WAVESHAPE
member.summary: Waveshaper distortions are used mainly by electronic musicians to achieve an extra-abrasive sound.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.Mode
member.summary: Distortion type. Default value: [code]MODE_CLIP[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.PreGain
member.summary: Increases or decreases the volume before the effect. Value can range from -60 to 60. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.KeepHfHz
member.summary: High-pass filter. Frequencies higher than this value will not be affected by the distortion. Value can range from 1 to 20000. Default value: [code]16000[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.Drive
member.summary: Distortion power. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectDistortion.PostGain
member.summary: Increases or decreases the volume after the effect. Value can range from -80 to 24. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectEQ
member.summary: AudioEffectEQ gives you control over frequencies. Use it to compensate for existing deficiencies in audio. AudioEffectEQ are very useful on the Master Bus to completely master a mix and give it character. They are also very useful when a game is run on a mobile device, to adjust the mix to that kind of speakers (it can be added but disabled when headphones are plugged).

member.name: M:Godot.AudioEffectEQ.SetBandGainDb(System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets band's gain at the specified index, in dB.

member.name: M:Godot.AudioEffectEQ.GetBandGainDb(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the band's gain at the specified index, in dB.

member.name: M:Godot.AudioEffectEQ.GetBandCount
member.summary: Returns the number of bands of the equalizer.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectEQ10
member.summary: Frequency bands : Band 1 : 31 Hz Band 2 : 62 Hz Band 3 : 125 Hz Band 4 : 250 Hz Band 5 : 500 Hz Band 6 : 1000 Hz Band 7 : 2000 Hz Band 8 : 4000 Hz Band 9 : 8000 Hz Band 10 : 16000 Hz See also [AudioEffectEQ], [AudioEffectEQ6], [AudioEffectEQ21].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectEQ21
member.summary: Frequency bands : Band 1 : 22 Hz Band 2 : 32 Hz Band 3 : 44 Hz Band 4 : 63 Hz Band 5 : 90 Hz Band 6 : 125 Hz Band 7 : 175 Hz Band 8 : 250 Hz Band 9 : 350 Hz Band 10 : 500 Hz Band 11 : 700 Hz Band 12 : 1000 Hz Band 13 : 1400 Hz Band 14 : 2000 Hz Band 15 : 2800 Hz Band 16 : 4000 Hz Band 17 : 5600 Hz Band 18 : 8000 Hz Band 19 : 11000 Hz Band 20 : 16000 Hz Band 21 : 22000 Hz See also [AudioEffectEQ], [AudioEffectEQ6], [AudioEffectEQ10].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectEQ6
member.summary: Frequency bands : Band 1 : 32 Hz Band 2 : 100 Hz Band 3 : 320 Hz Band 4 : 1000 Hz Band 5 : 3200 Hz Band 6 : 10000 Hz See also [AudioEffectEQ], [AudioEffectEQ10], [AudioEffectEQ21].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectFilter
member.summary: Allows frequencies other than the [member cutoff_hz] to pass.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectFilter.CutoffHz
member.summary: Threshold frequency for the filter.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectFilter.Resonance
member.summary: Amount of boost in the overtones near the cutoff frequency.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectFilter.Gain
member.summary: Gain amount of the frequencies after the filter.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectHighPassFilter
member.summary: Cuts frequencies lower than the [member cutoff_hz] and allows higher frequencies to pass.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectLimiter
member.summary: A limiter is similar to a compressor, but it’s less flexible and designed to disallow sound going over a given dB threshold. Adding one in the Master Bus is always recommended to reduce the effects of clipping. Soft clipping starts to reduce the peaks a little below the threshold level and progressively increases its effect as the input level increases such that the threshold is never exceeded.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectLimiter.CeilingDb
member.summary: The waveform's maximum allowed value. Value can range from -20 to -0.1. Default value: [code]-0.1dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectLimiter.ThresholdDb
member.summary: Threshold from which the limiter begins to be active. Value can range from -30 to 0. Default value: [code]0dB[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectLimiter.SoftClipDb
member.summary: Applies a gain to the limited waves. Value can range from 0 to 6. Default value: [code]2dB[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectLowPassFilter
member.summary: Cuts frequencies higher than the [member cutoff_hz] and allows lower frequencies to pass.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectNotchFilter
member.summary: Attenuates frequencies in a narrow band around the [member cutoff_hz] and cuts frequencies outside of this range.

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectPanner
member.summary: Determines how much of an audio signal is sent to the left and right buses.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPanner.Pan
member.summary: Pan position. Value can range from -1 (fully left) to 1 (fully right).

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser
member.summary: Combines phase-shifted signals with the original signal. The movement of the phase-shifted signals is controlled using a Low Frequency Oscillator.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.RangeMinHz
member.summary: Determines the minimum frequency affected by the LFO modulations. Value can range from 10 to 10000. Default value: [code]440hz[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.RangeMaxHz
member.summary: Determines the maximum frequency affected by the LFO modulations. Value can range from 10 to 10000. Default value: [code]1600hz[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.RateHz
member.summary: Adjusts the rate at which the effect sweeps up and down across the frequency range.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.Feedback
member.summary: Output percent of modified sound. Value can range from 0.1 to 0.9. Default value: [code]0.7[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPhaser.Depth
member.summary: Governs how high the filter frequencies sweep. Low value will primarily affect bass frequencies. High value can sweep high into the treble. Value can range from 0.1 to 4. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectPitchShift
member.summary: Allows modulation of pitch independently of tempo. All frequencies can be increased/decreased with minimal effect on transients.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectPitchShift.PitchScale
member.summary: Pitch value. Can range from 0 (-1 octave) to 16 (+16 octaves).

member.name: T:Godot.AudioEffectReverb
member.summary: Simulates rooms of different sizes. Its parameters can be adjusted to simulate the sound of a specific room.

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.PredelayMsec
member.summary: Time between the original signal and the early reflections of the reverb signal. Default value: [code]150ms[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.PredelayFeedback
member.summary: Output percent of predelay. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.RoomSize
member.summary: Dimensions of simulated room. Bigger means more echoes. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]0.8[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Damping
member.summary: Widens or narrows the stereo image of the reverb tail. 1 means fully widens. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Spread
member.summary: Defines how reflective the imaginary room's walls are. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Hipass
member.summary: High-pass filter passes signals with a frequency higher than a certain cutoff frequency and attenuates signals with frequencies lower than the cutoff frequency. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]0[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Dry
member.summary: Output percent of original sound. At 0, only modified sound is outputted. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]1[/code].

member.name: P:Godot.AudioEffectReverb.Wet
member.summary: Output percent of modified sound. At 0, only original sound is outputted. Value can range from 0 to 1. Default value: [code]0.5[/code].

member.summary: If [code]true[/code] the bus at index [code]bus_idx[/code] is bypassing effects.

member.name: T:Godot.BackBufferCopy
member.summary: Node for back-buffering the currently displayed screen. The region defined in the BackBufferCopy node is bufferized with the content of the screen it covers, or the entire screen according to the copy mode set. Accessing this buffer is done with the texscreen() shader instruction.

member.name: F:Godot.BackBufferCopy.COPY_MODE_DISABLED
member.summary: Disables the buffering mode. This means the BackBufferCopy node will directly use the portion of screen it covers.
