member.name: T:Godot.Tween
member.summary: Node useful for animations with unknown start and end points, procedural animations, making one node follow another, and other simple behavior. Because it is easy to get it wrong, here is a quick usage example: [codeblock] var tween = get_node("Tween") tween.interpolate_property(get_node("Node2D_to_move"), "transform/origin", Vector2(0,0), Vector2(100,100), 1, Tween.TRANS_LINEAR, Tween.EASE_IN_OUT) tween.start() [/codeblock] Some of the methods of this class require a property name. You can get the property name by hovering over the property in the inspector of the editor. Many of the methods accept [code]trans_type[/code] and [code]ease_type[/code]. The first accepts an TRANS_* constant, and refers to the way the timing of the animation is handled (you might want to see [code]http://easings.net/[/code] for some examples). The second accepts an EASE_* constant, and controls the where [code]trans_type[/code] is applied to the interpolation (in the beginning, the end, or both). If you don't know which transition and easing to pick, you can try different TRANS_* constants with EASE_IN_OUT, and use the one that looks best.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TWEEN_PROCESS_PHYSICS
member.summary: The [code]Tween[/code] should use [code]_physics_process[/code] for timekeeping when this is enabled.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TWEEN_PROCESS_IDLE
member.summary: The [code]Tween[/code] should use [code]_process[/code] for timekeeping when this is enabled (default).

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_LINEAR
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated linearly.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_SINE
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated using a sine wave.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_QUINT
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated with a quinary (to the power of 5) function.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_QUART
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated with a quartic (to the power of 4) function.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_QUAD
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated with a quadratic (to the power of 2) function.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_EXPO
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated with an exponential (some number to the power of x) function.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_ELASTIC
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated with elasticity, wiggling around the edges.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_CUBIC
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated with a cubic (to the power of 3) function.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_CIRC
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated with a function using square roots.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_BOUNCE
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated by bouncing at, but never surpassing, the end.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.TRANS_BACK
member.summary: Means that the animation is interpolated backing out at edges.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.EASE_IN
member.summary: Signifies that the interpolation should be focused in the beginning.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.EASE_OUT
member.summary: Signifies that the interpolation should be focused in the end.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.EASE_IN_OUT
member.summary: Signifies that the interpolation should be focused in both ends.

member.name: F:Godot.Tween.EASE_OUT_IN
member.summary: Signifies that the interpolation should be focused in both ends, but they should be switched (a bit hard to explain, try it for yourself to be sure).

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.IsActive
member.summary: Returns true if any tweens are currently running, and false otherwise. Note that this method doesn't consider tweens that have ended.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.SetActive(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Activate/deactivate the tween. You can use this for pausing animations, though [method stop_all] and [method resume_all] might be more fit for this.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.IsRepeat
member.summary: Returns true if repeat has been set from editor GUI or [method set_repeat].

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.SetRepeat(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Make the tween repeat after all tweens have finished.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.SetSpeedScale(System.Single)
member.summary: Set the speed multiplier of the tween. Set it to 1 for normal speed, 2 for two times nromal speed, and 0.5 for half of the normal speed. Setting it to 0 would pause the animation, but you might consider using [method set_active] or [method stop_all] and [method resume_all] for this.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.GetSpeedScale
member.summary: Returns the speed that has been set from editor GUI or [method set_repeat].

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.SetTweenProcessMode(System.Int32)
member.summary: Set whether the Tween uses [code]_process[/code] or [code]_physics_process[/code] (accepts TWEEN_PROCESS_IDLE and TWEEN_PROCESS_PHYSICS constants, respectively).

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.GetTweenProcessMode
member.summary: Returns the process mode that has been set from editor GUI or [method set_tween_process_mode]

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.Start
member.summary: Start the tween node. You can define tweens both before and after this.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.Reset(Godot.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Resets a tween to the initial value (the one given, not the one before the tween), given its object and property/method pair. Passing empty String as key will reset all tweens for given object.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.ResetAll
member.summary: Resets all tweens to their initial values (the ones given, not those before the tween).

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.Stop(Godot.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Stop animating a tween, given its object and property/method pair. Passing empty String as key will stop all tweens for given object.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.StopAll
member.summary: Stop animating all tweens.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.Resume(Godot.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Continue animating a stopped tween, given its object and property/method pair. Passing empty String as key will resume all tweens for given object.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.ResumeAll
member.summary: Continue animating all stopped tweens.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.Remove(Godot.Object,System.String)
member.summary: Stop animating and completely remove a tween, given its object and property/method pair. Passing empty String as key will remove all tweens for given object.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.RemoveAll
member.summary: Stop animating and completely remove all tweens.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.Seek(System.Single)
member.summary: Seek the animation to the given [code]time[/code] in seconds.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.Tell
member.summary: Returns the current time of the tween.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.GetRuntime
member.summary: Returns the time needed for all tweens to end in seconds, measured from the start. Thus, if you have two tweens, one ending 10 seconds after the start and the other - 20 seconds, it would return 20 seconds, as by that time all tweens would have finished.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.InterpolateProperty(Godot.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Animate [code]property[/code] of [code]object[/code] from [code]initial_val[/code] to [code]final_val[/code] for [code]duration[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later. [code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the beginning, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.InterpolateMethod(Godot.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Animate [code]method[/code] of [code]object[/code] from [code]initial_val[/code] to [code]final_val[/code] for [code]duration[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later. Methods are animated by calling them with consecutive values. [code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the beginning, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.InterpolateCallback(Godot.Object,System.Single,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Call [code]callback[/code] of [code]object[/code] after [code]duration[/code]. [code]arg1[/code]-[code]arg5[/code] are arguments to be passed to the callback.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.InterpolateDeferredCallback(Godot.Object,System.Single,System.String,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object,System.Object)
member.summary: Call [code]callback[/code] of [code]object[/code] after [code]duration[/code] on the main thread (similar to [method Object.call_deferred]). [code]arg1[/code]-[code]arg5[/code] are arguments to be passed to the callback.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.FollowProperty(Godot.Object,System.String,System.Object,Godot.Object,System.String,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Follow [code]property[/code] of [code]object[/code] and apply it on [code]target_property[/code] of [code]target[/code], beginning from [code]initial_val[/code] for [code]duration[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later. Note that [code]target:target_property[/code] would equal [code]object:property[/code] at the end of the tween. [code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the beginning, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.FollowMethod(Godot.Object,System.String,System.Object,Godot.Object,System.String,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Follow [code]method[/code] of [code]object[/code] and apply the returned value on [code]target_method[/code] of [code]target[/code], beginning from [code]initial_val[/code] for [code]duration[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] later. Methods are animated by calling them with consequitive values. [code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the beginning, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.TargetingProperty(Godot.Object,System.String,Godot.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Animate [code]property[/code] of [code]object[/code] from the current value of the [code]initial_val[/code] property of [code]initial[/code] to [code]final_val[/code] for [code]duration[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later. [code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the beginning, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.

member.name: M:Godot.Tween.TargetingMethod(Godot.Object,System.String,Godot.Object,System.String,System.Object,System.Single,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Single)
member.summary: Animate [code]method[/code] of [code]object[/code] from the value returned by [code]initial.initial_method[/code] to [code]final_val[/code] for [code]duration[/code] seconds, [code]delay[/code] seconds later. Methods are animated by calling them with consecutive values. [code]trans_type[/code] accepts TRANS_* constants, and is the way the animation is interpolated, while [code]ease_type[/code] accepts EASE_* constants, and controls the place of the interpolation (the beginning, the end, or both). You can read more about them in the class description.

member.name: T:Godot.UndoRedo
member.summary: Helper to manage UndoRedo in the editor or custom tools. It works by storing calls to functions in both 'do' an 'undo' lists. Common behavior is to create an action, then add do/undo calls to functions or property changes, then committing the action.

member.name: M:Godot.UndoRedo.CreateAction(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a new action. After this is called, do all your calls to [method add_do_method], [method add_undo_method], [method add_do_property] and [method add_undo_property].

member.name: M:Godot.UndoRedo.CommitAction
member.summary: Commit the action. All 'do' methods/properties are called/set when this function is called.

member.name: M:Godot.UndoRedo.AddDoProperty(Godot.Object,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Set a property with a custom value.

member.name: M:Godot.UndoRedo.AddUndoProperty(Godot.Object,System.String,System.Object)
member.summary: Undo setting of a property with a custom value.

member.name: M:Godot.UndoRedo.AddDoReference(Godot.Object)
member.summary: Add a 'do' reference that will be erased if the 'do' history is lost. This is useful mostly for new nodes created for the 'do' call. Do not use for resources.

member.name: M:Godot.UndoRedo.AddUndoReference(Godot.Object)
member.summary: Add an 'undo' reference that will be erased if the 'undo' history is lost. This is useful mostly for nodes removed with the 'do' call (not the 'undo' call!).

member.name: M:Godot.UndoRedo.ClearHistory
member.summary: Clear the undo/redo history and associated references.

member.name: M:Godot.UndoRedo.GetCurrentActionName
member.summary: Get the name of the current action.

member.name: M:Godot.UndoRedo.GetVersion
member.summary: Get the version, each time a new action is committed, the version number of the UndoRedo is increased automatically. This is useful mostly to check if something changed from a saved version.

member.name: T:Godot.Viewport
member.summary: A Viewport creates a different view into the screen, or a sub-view inside another viewport. Children 2D Nodes will display on it, and children Camera 3D nodes will render on it too. Optionally, a viewport can have its own 2D or 3D world, so they don't share what they draw with other viewports. If a viewport is a child of a [Control], it will automatically take up its same rect and position, otherwise they must be set manually. Viewports can also choose to be audio listeners, so they generate positional audio depending on a 2D or 3D camera child of it. Also, viewports can be assigned to different screens in case the devices have multiple screens. Finally, viewports can also behave as render targets, in which case they will not be visible unless the associated texture is used to draw.

member.name: F:Godot.Viewport.UPDATE_DISABLED
member.summary: Do not update the render target.

member.name: F:Godot.Viewport.UPDATE_ONCE
member.summary: Update the render target once, then switch to [code]UPDATE_DISABLED[/code]

member.name: F:Godot.Viewport.UPDATE_WHEN_VISIBLE
member.summary: Update the render target only when it is visible. This is the default value.

member.name: M:Godot.Viewport.SetUseArvr(System.Boolean)
member.summary: If true this viewport will be bound to our ARVR Server. If this is our main Godot viewport our AR/VR output will be displayed on screen. If output is redirected to an HMD we'll see the output of just one of the eyes without any distortion applied else we'll see the stereo buffer with distortion applied if applicable If this is an extra viewport output will only work if redirection to an HMD is supported by the interface. The render target will allow you to use the undistorted output for the right eye in the display.

member.name: M:Godot.Viewport.UseArvr
member.summary: Returns whether this viewport is using our ARVR Server

member.summary: Return the square root of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_FMOD

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_FPOSMOD

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_FLOOR

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_CEIL

member.summary: Return the input rounded to the nearest integer.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_ABS
member.summary: Return the absolute value of the input.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_SIGN
member.summary: Return the sign of the input, turning it into 1, -1, or 0. Useful to determine if the input is positive or negative.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_POW
member.summary: Return the input raised to a given power.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_LOG
member.summary: Return the natural logarithm of the input. Note that this is not the typical base-10 logarithm function calculators use.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_EXP
member.summary: Return [b]e[/b] raised to the power of the input. [b]e[/b] sometimes called "Euler's number" is a mathematical constant whose value is approximately 2.71828.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_ISNAN
member.summary: Return whether the input is NaN (Not a Number) or not. NaN is usually produced by dividing 0 by 0, though other ways exist.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_ISINF
member.summary: Return whether the input is an infinite floating-point number or not. Infinity is usually produced by dividing a number by 0, though other ways exist.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_EASE
member.summary: Easing function, based on exponent. 0 is constant, 1 is linear, 0 to 1 is ease-in, 1+ is ease out. Negative values are in-out/out in.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_DECIMALS
member.summary: Return the number of digit places after the decimal that the first non-zero digit occurs.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_STEPIFY
member.summary: Return the input snapped to a given step.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_LERP
member.summary: Return a number linearly interpolated between the first two inputs, based on the third input. Uses the formula [code]a + (a - b) * t[/code].

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_DECTIME
member.summary: Return the result of 'value' decreased by 'step' * 'amount'.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_RANDOMIZE
member.summary: Randomize the seed (or the internal state) of the random number generator. Current implementation reseeds using a number based on time.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_RAND
member.summary: Return a random 32 bits integer value. To obtain a random value between 0 to N (where N is smaller than 2^32 - 1), you can use it with the remainder function.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_RANDF
member.summary: Return a random floating-point value between 0 and 1. To obtain a random value between 0 to N, you can use it with multiplication.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_RANDOM
member.summary: Return a random floating-point value between the two inputs.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptBuiltinFunc.MATH_RANDSEED

member.name: T:Godot.VisualScriptCondition
member.summary: A Visual Script node that checks a [bool] input port. If [code]true[/code] it will exit via the “true” sequence port. If [code]false[/code] it will exit via the "false" sequence port. After exiting either, it exits via the “done” port. Sequence ports may be left disconnected. [b]Input Ports:[/b] - Sequence: [code]if (cond) is[/code] - Data (boolean): [code]cond[/code] [b]Output Ports:[/b] - Sequence: [code]true[/code] - Sequence: [code]false[/code] - Sequence: [code]done[/code]

Has roughly the following structure: [codeblock] { name = "string", args = [{ name = "string" class_name = "string" type = TYPE_* hint = PROPERTY_HINT_* hint_string = "string" }] default_args = [] # Array of variants flags = METHOD_FLAG_* id = 0 return = {type = TYPE_*} } [/codeblock]

member.name: T:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode
member.summary: A custom Visual Script node which can be scripted in powerful ways.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.START_MODE_BEGIN_SEQUENCE
member.summary: The start mode used the first time when [method _step] is called.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.START_MODE_CONTINUE_SEQUENCE
member.summary: The start mode used when [method _step] is called after coming back from a STEP_PUSH_STACK_BIT.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.START_MODE_RESUME_YIELD
member.summary: The start mode used when [method _step] is called after resuming from STEP_YIELD_BIT.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.STEP_PUSH_STACK_BIT
member.summary: Hint used by [method _step] to tell that control should return to it when there is no other node left to execute. This is used by [VisualScriptCondition] to redirect the sequence to the "Done" port after the true/false branch has finished execution.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.STEP_GO_BACK_BIT
member.summary: Hint used by [method _step] to tell that control should return back, either hitting a previous STEP_PUSH_STACK_BIT or exiting the function.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.STEP_EXIT_FUNCTION_BIT
member.summary: Hint used by [method _step] to tell that control should stop and exit the function.

member.name: F:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode.STEP_YIELD_BIT
member.summary: Hint used by [method _step] to tell that the function should be yielded. Using this requires you to have at least one working memory slot, which is used for the [VisualScriptFunctionState].

member.summary: Return the specified output's type. See the TYPE_* enum in [@GlobalScope].

member.name: M:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode._GetText
member.summary: Return the custom node's text, which is shown right next to the input [b]sequence[/b] port (if there is none, on the place that is usually taken by it).

member.name: M:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode._GetWorkingMemorySize
member.summary: Return the size of the custom node's working memory. See [method _step] for more details.

member.name: M:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode._HasInputSequencePort
member.summary: Return whether the custom node has an input [b]sequence[/b] port.

member.name: M:Godot.VisualScriptCustomNode._Step(System.Object[],System.Object[],System.Int32,System.Object[])
member.summary:
Execute the custom node's logic, returning the index of the output sequence port to use or a [String] when there is an error.
The [code]inputs[/code] array contains the values of the input ports. [code]outputs[/code] is an array whose indices should be set to the respective outputs. The [code]start_mode[/code] is usually [code]START_MODE_BEGIN_SEQUENCE[/code], unless you have used the STEP_* constants. [code]working_mem[/code] is an array which can be used to persist information between runs of the custom node.
When returning, you can mask the returned value with one of the STEP_* constants.

member.name: T:Godot.VSplitContainer

member.name: T:Godot.WeakRef
member.summary: A weakref can hold a [Reference], without contributing to the reference counter. A weakref can be created from an [Object] using [method @GDScript.weakref]. If this object is not a reference, weakref still works, however, it does not have any effect on the object. Weakrefs are useful in cases where multiple classes have variables that refer to each other. Without weakrefs, using these classes could lead to memory leaks, since both references keep each other from being released. Making part of the variables a weakref can prevent this cyclic dependency, and allows the references to be released.

member.name: M:Godot.WeakRef.GetRef
member.summary: Returns the [Object] this weakref is referring to.

member.summary: Class that has everything pertaining to a world. A physics space, a visual scenario and a sound space. Spatial nodes register their resources into the current world.

member.summary: Retrieve the [RID] of this world's canvas resource. Used by the [VisualServer] for 2D drawing.

member.name: M:Godot.World2D.GetDirectSpaceState
member.summary: Retrieve the state of this world's physics space. This allows arbitrary querying for collision.

member.name: T:Godot.WorldEnvironment
member.summary: The [code]WorldEnvironment[/code] node can be added to a scene in order to set default [Environment] variables for the scene. The [code]WorldEnvironment[/code] can be overridden by an [Environment] node set on the current [Camera]. Additionally, only one [code]WorldEnvironment[/code] may be instanced in a given scene at a time. The [code]WorldEnvironment[/code] allows the user to specify default lighting parameters (e.g. ambient lighting), various post-processing effects (e.g. SSAO, DOF, Tonemapping), and how to draw the background (e.g. solid color, skybox).

member.name: M:Godot.WorldEnvironment.SetEnvironment(Godot.Environment)
member.summary: Set the currently bound [Environment] to the one specified.

member.name: M:Godot.WorldEnvironment.GetEnvironment
member.summary: Return the [Environment] currently bound.

member.name: T:Godot.XMLParser
member.summary: This class can serve as base to make custom XML parsers. Since XML is a very flexible standard, this interface is low level so it can be applied to any possible schema.

member.name: F:Godot.XMLParser.NODE_NONE
member.summary: There's no node (no file or buffer opened)

member.name: F:Godot.XMLParser.NODE_ELEMENT
member.summary: Element (tag)

member.name: F:Godot.XMLParser.NODE_ELEMENT_END
member.summary: End of element

member.name: F:Godot.XMLParser.NODE_TEXT
member.summary: Text node

member.name: F:Godot.XMLParser.NODE_COMMENT
member.summary: Comment node

member.name: F:Godot.XMLParser.NODE_CDATA
member.summary: CDATA content

member.name: F:Godot.XMLParser.NODE_UNKNOWN
member.summary: Unknown node

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.Read
member.summary: Read the next node of the file. This returns an error code.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetNodeType
member.summary: Get the type of the current node. Compare with [code]NODE_*[/code] constants.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetNodeName
member.summary: Get the name of the current element node. This will raise an error if the current node type is not [code]NODE_ELEMENT[/code] nor [code]NODE_ELEMENT_END[/code]

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetNodeData
member.summary: Get the contents of a text node. This will raise an error in any other type of node.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetNodeOffset
member.summary: Get the byte offset of the current node since the beginning of the file or buffer.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetAttributeCount
member.summary: Get the amount of attributes in the current element.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetAttributeName(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the name of the attribute specified by the index in [code]idx[/code] argument.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetAttributeValue(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the value of the attribute specified by the index in [code]idx[/code] argument.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.HasAttribute(System.String)
member.summary: Check whether or not the current element has a certain attribute.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetNamedAttributeValue(System.String)
member.summary: Get the value of a certain attribute of the current element by name. This will raise an error if the element has no such attribute.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetNamedAttributeValueSafe(System.String)
member.summary: Get the value of a certain attribute of the current element by name. This will return an empty [String] if the attribute is not found.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.IsEmpty
member.summary: Check whether the current element is empty (this only works for completely empty tags, e.g. <element \>).

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.GetCurrentLine
member.summary: Get the current line in the parsed file (currently not implemented).

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.SkipSection
member.summary: Skips the current section. If the node contains other elements, they will be ignored and the cursor will go to the closing of the current element.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.Seek(System.Int32)
member.summary: Move the buffer cursor to a certain offset (since the beginning) and read the next node there. This returns an error code.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.Open(System.String)
member.summary: Open a XML file for parsing. This returns an error code.

member.name: M:Godot.XMLParser.OpenBuffer(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Open a XML raw buffer for parsing. This returns an error code.

member.name: T:Godot.YSort
member.summary: Sort all child nodes based on their Y positions. The child node must inherit from [CanvasItem] for it to be sorted. Nodes that have a higher Y position will be drawn later, so they will appear on top of nodes that have a lower Y position.

member.name: M:Godot.YSort.SetSortEnabled(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set whether the children nodes are sorted or not. (default true)

member.name: M:Godot.YSort.IsSortEnabled
member.summary: Returns true if the children nodes are being sorted.
